message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms described indicate nerve damage, especially of the femoral nerve. The decreased sensation, weakness in hip flexion and knee extension, and decreased patellar reflex on the left indicate femoral nerve injury. The surgical incision is without erythema or drainage, ruling out surgical site infection. Sural nerve injury and femoral artery occlusion are less likely causes of these symptoms.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms suggest a nerve injury, and among the options, femoral nerve injury is the most likely cause as it innervates the anterior thigh muscles and the skin of the anterior and medial thigh, which is where the symptoms are located. The decreased patellar reflex also supports this hypothesis. The absence of erythema or drainage near the surgical incision makes surgical site infection unlikely. Sural nerve injury is unlikely as it innervates the skin of the lateral foot and ankle. Femoral artery occlusion is unlikely as there are normal pulses in the affected leg.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and neurologic exam findings suggest a femoral nerve injury. The decreased sensation and weakness in left leg are consistent with femoral nerve involvement, and the absence of erythema or drainage in surgical incision eliminates the possibility of surgical site infection. Sural nerve injury would not cause weakness in hip flexion and knee extension, and femoral artery occlusion would cause loss of pulses in the affected leg.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms suggest a nerve injury, and the most likely nerve injured is the femoral nerve. The decreased strength in hip flexion and knee extension, as well as the decreased patellar reflex, support this diagnosis. Surgical site infection or femoral artery occlusion would present with different symptoms and examination findings.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient's symptoms indicate a nerve injury, and the distribution of the sensory loss and weakness point towards damage to the femoral nerve. The absence of erythema or drainage from the surgical incision suggests that surgical site infection is less likely, and the pulses indicate that femoral artery occlusion is not the cause of the symptoms. Sural nerve injury would not cause weakness in hip flexion and knee extension.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms suggest a nerve injury, and specifically, a femoral nerve injury. The decreased strength on hip flexion and knee extension, and decreased patellar reflex, all suggest involvement of the femoral nerve. Surgical site infection would likely be accompanied by erythema and/or drainage at the surgical incision site, which is not present in this case. Sural nerve injury would only involve sensation on the lower leg and not the thigh. Femoral artery occlusion would result in decreased or absent pulses and ischemic symptoms.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms suggest that the most likely underlying cause is Femoral nerve injury. The prickling sensation and decreased sensation to pinprick and light touch on the anteromedial left thigh as well as medial lower leg are consistent with femoral nerve injury, and the decreased reflex on the left supports this diagnosis. The surgical site appears to be without infection, ruling out option (B). There is no evidence of vascular compromise to suggest femoral artery occlusion, making option (D) less likely. Sural nerve injury is also a possibility, but the symptoms are more consistent with femoral nerve injury.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms suggest an injury to the femoral nerve, as it innervates the quadriceps muscle (hip flexion and knee extension), and the sensory distribution on the anterior and medial thigh and leg. There are no signs of infection or vascular compromise, ruling out options B and D. Option C, sural nerve injury, typically involves the lateral leg.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms suggest nerve injury, and the decreased sensation to pinprick and light touch on the anteromedial left thigh as well as the decreased patellar reflex on the left suggests femoral nerve injury. The surgical incision without erythema or drainage suggests that surgical site infection is unlikely. Sural nerve injury and femoral artery occlusion do not fit with the presenting symptoms.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and physical exam findings suggest a femoral nerve injury, which can be a complication of hip surgery. Surgical site infection would have erythema or drainage at the incision site, and femoral artery occlusion would cause decreased pulses and more severe symptoms. Sural nerve injury would not cause weakness in hip extension or decreased patellar reflex.
